Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: From Search to Research with Fast Patent-document Correlations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project attempts to address a fundamental question for innovators: is my idea already patented? This do-it-yourself-initially service will empower small-business enterprises with synthesized research of over 10 million patent documents within 10 minutes based on the concepts contained within the idea. Such a comprehensive, real-time, low-cost offering is currently unavailable for small-business entrepreneurs. Current search tools do not synthesize the results into an executive summary, do not allow an entire document to be entered as the search input, and do not perform real-time concept/correlation computations. This proposed innovation will enable the inventor to submit an entire document (the idea) as the search query; then, utilizing network mathematics and artificial-intelligence algorithms, this service will synthesize search results in real-time summarizing what patent documents are most related to the idea based on natural-language processing. Such a service for small-business entrepreneurs would enable them to initially ascertain the novelty of their idea and give them an on-the-go education about the natural language used in patent documents in comparison to their idea. This meta-innovation would objectively ascertain the intellectual-property merit of any proposed technology, enable small-business innovators, and foster the acceleration of innovation development in the United States.

The development of latent semantic analysis (LSA) has enabled algorithm development to extract latent (or hidden) semantic structure from documents addressing two important word-sense ambiguity issues that text-matching search cannot: polysemy (single term with multiple meanings; i.e., strike as to hit [verb], to start up [verb], or to cease working [noun]) and synonymy (multiple terms with single meaning; i.e., car and automobile). Albeit robust, this concept-search approach for large document collections is not tractable due to the high-complexity computational requirements for performing matrix singular value decomposition (SVD) necessary for LSA. Approximation techniques that use subset approaches necessarily introduce some amount of systematic error. To ascertain the most relevant documents in a large collection for a given focal document, this proposed innovation (search-subset LSA) will subset using proprietary search methodologies without any systematic error, reducing both the number of documents to compare and the number of terms to analyze thereby making real-time document correlations possible. The aims of this research are: to identify the optimal subset approach for comprehensive nomological capture of top-correlation candidates, to ascertain optimal input parameters for the focal query document, and to develop a statistical test to confirm that no systematic bias is present in this approach.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hello, my name is Monte Shaffer and I am the founder of Entrepreneurial Innovation.  In this report I am presenting MyPatentIdeas, an automated system to rapidly assess the merit of an idea.  Idea evaluation is essential for an entrepreneur to assess the intellectual-property landscape as efforts are made to commercialize.  Startup entrepreneurs have limited resources:  time and money.  Should they spend $350 per hour for a patent attorney to begin drafting a patent application?  Should they pay $2000 for a professional patent-search report (which can take weeks) before beginning the application process?  Is their idea worth patenting?  Or, do they have freedom to commercialize their idea in the marketplace?


Although the market is saturated with many patent-analytics tools to assess patent information, none offer an automated search process.  Current services can be categorized into three broad categories:  self-service free tools (e.g., USPTO, Lens, etc.); self-service enterprise solutions (e.g., Reed Tech, Thomson Innovation , Innography ); full-service search searches [e.g., online such as Legal Zoom or offline such as outsourcing to India or to a more reputable U.S. search firm]).


As a micro-enterprise, this funding has been essential for our company to move forward with our ambitious R&D program aligning with the NSF goals of a program that represents transformative research:  challenging conventions through new techniques that may ultimately redefine the marketplace. Our research and development program is about automating patent search in a smart way.  Using sound statistical processes to the analysis of patent language, we can process your idea, compare it to the corpus of U.S. patent documents, and then perform real-time analysis on a relevant subset.  In our research, we have developed custom artificial-intelligence algorithms to automate the process.


Our SBIR Phase I award was granted by the National Science Foundation (NSF) based on two components of merit:  intellectual merit (for the development of unique applications) and societal impact.  At the NSF, our R&D program is classified as EA4:  Entrepreneurship Education and our program manager was Glenn Larsen.  We are very happy with the guidance and direction he provided. 


Real-time latent-semantic analysis is intractable with large document collections.  The traditional work around is to create a static index of the document collection using only a portion or subset of the collection.  Such an approach has limitations when the document collection contains technical language that may be unique, a requirement for patent documents.  Our innovation is a real-time solution that uses an automated query-building system to determine a subset of relevant documents, from which, the real-time analysis can be performed.  The overall research goal of Phase I was to validate this approach, which we identified as “nomological capture” – does our subset searching methodology precisely contain all potential nearest neighbors?


In our research, we have developed custom artificial-intelligence algorithms to automate the entire process.


This Phase I project was very productive and the primary result was to identify that our research program has technical feasibility.  We have been able to implement the system and in the beta-launch get some initial feedback that aligns with our research experiments – the nearest neighbors we identified have some degree of face validity.  


We worked closely with our commercialization coach Dawn Breaker, and felt like their services were invaluable for us to understand the market environment.  They provided tremendous support enabling us to refine our thinking and articulate our distinctive competencies.


Regrettably, we intentionally chose NOT to submit a Phase II proposal.  There were several factors for this decision:


1.  Our program manager Glenn Larsen retired, and our relationship with NSF moving forward was unknown based on internal uncertainties about his immediate replacement.
2.  We have submitted a Phase II proposal before and believe that the "wannabes" that serve as panelists that have any knowledge/expertise in the patent domain (who have significant influence over the other panel members) are inherently biased against this type of service (an AI may put them out of a job and disrupt that status quo).  This inherent conflict of interest based on an ingrained worldview is a challenge for NSF to address due to the structural constraints of the review process.  
3.  The NSF regulations have become suffocating to true entrepreneurs and have shifted the focus from enabling innovation to further supporting university-research programs.  A distributed team working out of home offices or garages just does not sound as "sexy" as a university team's natural ecosystem.  We believe this is contrary to the mission of the NSF yet understand why this is happening.  Congress (e.g., Rand Paul) wants to make certain the money is spent appropriately.  Bad press (Treadmills for shrimp or sexual habits of cocained quail) create some challenges for SBIR programs.  To respond, NSF has hired more bean counters and implemented audit protocols that stifles the innovative process, ironically creating more regulations in the era of Trump.  


Last Modified: 04/25/2018
Modified by: Monte J Shaffer

    Monte J Shaffer
    B2C Wizard
  • The custom report takes about 10 minutes to process using sophisticated computing algorithms. Over 2000 patent documents are deeply analyzed with 1-2 million phrases being considered. The final report has significant details to educate entrepreneurs about the competitive landscape.
    Monte J. Shaffer
    Creative Commons
    Monte J Shaffer
    Custom Reporting
  • To demonstrate the custom report, we entered the contents of this Phase I proposal. The output demonstrates a white-label report that can be sold in a B2C model (see http://ideafit.us for more details).
    Monte J. Shaffer
    Creative Commons
    Monte J Shaffer
    Executive Summary Page 1
  • The "mall map" visually displays the location of your idea relative to existing patent documents.
    Monte J. Shaffer

    Monte J Shaffer
    Executive Summary Page 2
